contractTextPreview: Landlord reserves the right to adjust rent to reflect fair market value on sixty (60) days' notice.

aiResponse.summary: Clause allows mid-term rent increase without tenant consent. It conflicts with fixed-term protections.
highRisk: Landlord can raise rent after 60 days even if lease has months remaining.
No explicit cap on the adjustment or reference to CPI/state guidelines.
mediumRisk: No carve-out for hardship or relocation costs if tenant declines new rate.
lowRisk: Notice period is defined but lacks delivery method requirements.
recommendations: Request addendum limiting increases to renewal period only.
Add requirement for certified mail notice and mutually signed agreement.
Document the landlord promise in writing before moving in.

contractTextPreview: Tenant shall pay a security deposit equal to two months' rent. Deposit may be used for any damages, cleaning, or unpaid rent at landlord's sole discretion.

aiResponse.summary: Security deposit exceeds Massachusetts legal limit and gives landlord excessive discretion over deductions.
highRisk: Massachusetts law limits security deposits to one month's rent maximum.
Landlord's sole discretion clause may violate tenant protection laws.
mediumRisk: No mention of required itemized statement of deductions within 30 days.
Missing information about interest payments on deposit.
lowRisk: No specified timeline for deposit return after move-out.
recommendations: Request reduction to one month's rent to comply with MA law.
Add clause requiring itemized deduction list within 30 days.
Request written confirmation of deposit account and annual interest.

contractTextPreview: Landlord may terminate this agreement immediately if tenant violates any term. Tenant waives right to cure period.

aiResponse.summary: Eviction clause attempts to waive tenant's legal right to notice and cure period, which is unenforceable in Massachusetts.
highRisk: Immediate termination without notice violates MA tenant protection laws.
Waiver of cure period is likely unenforceable but signals aggressive landlord.
mediumRisk: No definition of what constitutes a violation.
lowRisk: Agreement type is month-to-month which offers flexibility.
recommendations: Strike the immediate termination and waiver language.
Add standard 30-day notice requirement for both parties.
Request clear definition of lease violations.

contractTextPreview: Tenant is responsible for all repairs and maintenance of the premises including plumbing, electrical, and HVAC systems.

aiResponse.summary: Clause improperly shifts landlord's legal maintenance obligations to tenant. This violates MA habitability requirements.
highRisk: Landlords are legally required to maintain plumbing, electrical, and heating systems.
Clause attempts to waive implied warranty of habitability.
mediumRisk: No distinction between normal wear and tenant-caused damage.
Missing emergency repair procedures and contact information.
lowRisk: Minor maintenance like changing light bulbs is reasonable for tenant.
recommendations: Strike language shifting major system maintenance to tenant.
Add clause specifying landlord responsibility for habitability items.
Request 24-hour emergency maintenance contact.

contractTextPreview: Subletting is strictly prohibited. Any attempt to sublet will result in immediate lease termination and forfeiture of security deposit.

aiResponse.summary: Sublease restriction is overly punitive. Forfeiture of deposit for subletting attempt may be unenforceable.
highRisk: Automatic deposit forfeiture is likely unenforceable as a penalty clause.
Immediate termination without cure period violates tenant rights.
mediumRisk: No provision for landlord consent to sublet in special circumstances.
No distinction between short-term guests and actual subletting.
lowRisk: Sublease restrictions themselves are generally enforceable.
recommendations: Request modification to allow subletting with landlord's written consent.
Strike deposit forfeiture language.
Add definition distinguishing guests from subtenants.

contractTextPreview: Tenant shall pay a monthly utility fee of $200 in addition to rent. This fee is non-refundable and not based on actual usage.

aiResponse.summary: Flat utility fee disconnected from actual usage may be unfair. Tenant has no way to reduce costs through conservation.
highRisk: No transparency on how $200 fee was calculated.
Non-refundable fee for utilities not actually used could be challenged.
mediumRisk: No provision for fee adjustment if utility rates change.
Missing information about which utilities are covered.
lowRisk: Flat fee provides predictable monthly costs.
recommendations: Request itemized breakdown of utility fee calculation.
Ask for actual usage billing or submeter installation.
Clarify exactly which utilities are included in the fee.

contractTextPreview: No pets allowed. Pet deposit of $500 non-refundable. Violation results in $50 per day fine until pet is removed.

aiResponse.summary: Pet policy contains contradictory terms and potentially excessive penalties.
highRisk: Policy says no pets but also mentions pet deposit - contradictory.
$50 daily fine may be unenforceable as an excessive penalty.
mediumRisk: No exception for service animals or emotional support animals as required by law.
Non-refundable pet deposit may violate MA security deposit laws.
lowRisk: Pet restrictions themselves are generally enforceable.
recommendations: Clarify whether pets are allowed with deposit or prohibited entirely.
Add required exception for service and emotional support animals.
Request pet deposit be refundable and counted toward deposit limit.

contractTextPreview: Lease automatically renews for successive 12-month terms unless tenant provides 90 days written notice. Rent may increase up to 15% upon renewal.

aiResponse.summary: Auto-renewal with long notice period and large potential rent increase creates risk of being locked in at higher rate.
highRisk: 15% rent increase cap is very high compared to typical 3-5% increases.
90-day notice requirement is longer than standard 30-60 days.
mediumRisk: Auto-renewal may catch tenant off guard if not calendared.
No requirement for landlord to notify tenant before renewal.
recommendations: Negotiate shorter notice period of 30-60 days.
Request rent increase cap of 5% or tied to CPI.
Add requirement for landlord reminder notice 120 days before renewal.

contractTextPreview: Landlord may enter premises at any time for inspection, repairs, or showing to prospective tenants without prior notice.

aiResponse.summary: Entry clause violates Massachusetts law requiring reasonable notice before landlord entry except in emergencies.
highRisk: MA law requires reasonable notice (typically 24 hours) before entry.
Entry at any time without notice violates tenant's right to quiet enjoyment.
mediumRisk: No distinction between emergency and non-emergency entry.
Showing to prospective tenants should be limited to final months of lease.
lowRisk: Landlord does have legitimate reasons to occasionally enter.
recommendations: Require 24-48 hour written notice for non-emergency entry.
Limit showing times to reasonable hours in final 60 days of lease.
Define what constitutes an emergency allowing immediate entry.

contractTextPreview: Standard residential lease agreement. Rent due on first of month. Security deposit equal to one month rent held in escrow. 30-day notice required for termination.

aiResponse.summary: This is a fairly standard lease with common terms that comply with Massachusetts rental laws.
mediumRisk: Should specify grace period for rent payment before late fees apply.
Missing information about where security deposit is held.
lowRisk: Could add more detail about maintenance request procedures.
Might benefit from clearer move-out inspection process.
recommendations: Request 5-day grace period for rent payment.
Ask for bank name and account info for security deposit.
Add move-out checklist to avoid deposit disputes.
